snippet.title: Tesla is making a risky move by issuing $1.5 billion in debt
snippet.content:
•Tesla will issue $US1.5 billion in unsecured notes.
•Issuing new debt deviates from previous equity based capital raises.
•The carmaker has added substantial debt to its balance sheet since its SolarCity merger last year.
Tesla , but the carmaker is doing so in a way that's different from previous funding rounds: it's issuing debt.
When has raised money over the past two years, it's sold more stock. And with the company seeing a massive uptick in its share price over the first half of 2017, much discussion swirled around whether CEO Elon Musk and his management team would head back to the public markets for more.
The stock is now up 65% year to date, so at one level selling more stock makes sense, but at another level, that would test the patience of existing investors, who would see their stakes further diluted.
On Tesla's second-quarter earnings call with analysts, Musk telegraphed his intent:
[T]here may be some wisdom in having a cash cushion for unexpected events. You just never know if there's going be some significant force majeure events in the world. It could be an earthquake in California, for example. But we're not at this point considering an equity raise. We are thinking about debt, but we're not thinking about an equity raise.
You can question the wisdom of this, but the decision has been made. Here's the release from the company:
Tesla today announced that it intends to offer, subject to market and other conditions, $US1.5 billion in aggregate principal amount of its senior notes due 2025 (the "Notes"). The Notes will be senior unsecured debt obligations of Tesla. The interest rate, redemption prices and other terms of the Notes are to be determined.
Tesla intends to use the net proceeds from this offering to further strengthen its balance sheet during this period of rapid scaling with the launch of Model 3, and for general corporate purposes.
Tesla's projected cash burn for the second half of 2017 would be about $US2 billion, leaving it with what the company considers a comfortable $US1 billion in reserve on the balance sheet.
But the bond sale suggests that Tesla doesn't want to start 2018 by cutting into that reserve. The critical issue for investors to consider here is the impact that adding another $US1.5 billion will have on Tesla's already increased debt levels, following its acquisition of SolarCity in late 2016.
The carmaker will now have in liabilities in less than 12 months.
